personal.title: Personal Information
phase.desc: This site will change as we test ideas.
start.intro: Answer a few questions to get a customized list of benefits for which you may be eligible and see how much money you could receive. This only suggests federal benefits at this time, and does not collect or track your information. See our Privacy policy and Terms and conditions for more information.
start.title: Money for COVID-19
wordmark.alt: Symbol of the Government of Canada
start.subtitle: Let’s find the benefits you may be eligible for
form.lost_job_c19: Did you stop working due to COVID-19?
form.why_stop_working.desc: Choose the description that best fits your situation:
You’ve been laid off due to COVID-19.
You’re self-employed and had to close.
You’re on unpaid leave from your work.
form.your_situation.desc: Choose the description that best fits your situation:
You were on parental leave recently, but: You were on parental leave recently, but you cannot return to work.
You were supposed to start a new job, bu: You were supposed to start a new job, but couldn’t due to COVID-19.
You’re working fewer hours than you were: You’re working fewer hours than you were before COVID-19.
You’re on paid leave from work.
You have not done any paid work in the l: You have not done any paid work in the last 12 months.
form.applied_to_EI: Have you applied for Employment Insurance (EI)?
You’ve applied for EI benefits, but have: You’ve applied for EI benefits, but haven’t heard back.
You quit or were let go due to unsafe wo: You quit or were let go due to unsafe working conditions.
result-ei-sickness.title: Based on what you’ve told us, you should apply for Employment Insurance (EI) Sickness Benefits.
result-ei-sickness.p2: Due to the COVID-19 crisis, we’ve waived the one-week waiting period so you can get paid faster. We also waived and the requirement for medical certification to make it easier to apply.
result-ei-sickness.p3:
Estimate of EI Sickness payments
If your application is approved, you will receive 55% of your gross income up to a maximum of $573 per week before taxes. The payments are sent out every two weeks. The number of weeks you get paid depends on how many “insurable hours” you worked in the last 52 weeks.
result-ccb-and-gst.title: Possible one-time payments
result-ccb-and-gst.p1: The Government of Canada is also issuing two one-time payments in May to help people cope with COVID-19.
result-ccb-and-gst.p2:
Canada Child Benefit
If you care for a child under 18, you will receive a one-time payment of $300 per child in May through the Canada Child Benefit.
result-ccb-and-gst.p3:
GST credit
If you receive the GST credit, you will also receive a one-time payment in May:
$400 for single people
$600 for couples.
result-ccb-and-gst.p4: Check your bank account to find out if you’ve been receiving either the Canada Child Benefit or the GST credit. Dates of payments are available. File your 2019 taxes sooner than later if you can to ensure you continue to receive them.
result-keep-receiving-ei.title: Keep receiving EI
result-keep-receiving-ei.p1: Do not stop your Employment Insurance (EI) benefits. You can apply for the new Canadian Economic Response Benefit if your EI runs out before October 3, 2020, and you’re still unemployed.
result-waiting-to-hear-back-from-ei.p1: If you’re waiting for a decision on your Employment Insurance (EI) application, do not reapply. If your EI application is denied, you can apply for the new Canadian Economic Response Benefit, once the application becomes available.
result-left-job-voluntarily.title: May be eligible for Employment Insurance
result-left-job-voluntarily.p1: If you left your job due to unsafe working conditions, you may be eligible for Employment Insurance (EI).
